sub_title: Full Professor and Research Director at Maastricht University
summary: I am Full Professor of International Security and Cooperation at Maastricht University, where I serve as the Director of the Research Programme "Politics and Culture in Europe". I lead two large research project: (1) an ERC project on the decline and death of international organisations (2019-2024); (2) an Horizon project on EU support for global governance reform (2023-2026).

awards.title: G.A. van Poelje Annual Prize
awards.description: This annual prize is given to the best dissertation on Public Administration defended in The Netherlands and Flanders.

awards.title: Otto von der Gablentz Academic Prize
awards.description: This biennial prize is given to the best dissertation on Germany or European Integration defended in The Netherlands in the two preceding years. The prize is named after the late and long-standing German ambassador to The Netherlands.

awards.title: Annual Prize for Best Article
awards.description: This prize is given to a scholar under the age of 35 for an article in the preceding year.

projects.title: Transforming and Defending Multilateralism: European Union Support for more Robust, Effective and Democratic Global Governance
projects.description:
Global governance and key multilateral institutions, such as the United Nations, World Trade Organization, and the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, are increasingly in trouble. They are challenged by emerging powers, such as China and other BRICS countries, which have different views on global order. The Russian war against Ukraine has further undermined international cooperation and caused gridlock across global governance. Nationalist populism, and particularly the Trump administration in the United States, have put the fragility of multilateralism on display.

This contestation of global governance is particularly concerning for Europe. The European Union (EU), which is an international organization itself, and its member states have long been key supporters of multilateralism and a system of global governance that is rules-based, effective, legitimate and democratic. What is more, many of the global challenges we are currently facing – climate change, pandemics, migration, inequalities and digitalisation – can only be tackled through cooperation.

The research project ENSURED examines how the EU and its members can transform and defend global governance to make it more robust, effective and democratic. This ENSURED project is coordinated by Maastricht University and includes 14 universities, think tanks and a civil society partner from Belgium, Czech Republic, Estonia, Germany, Italy, The Netherlands as well as Brazil, China, India, South Africa and the United States. ENSURED is funded for three years through the EU Horizon research programme.

contributors.headline: Full Professor and Research Director at Maastricht University

projects.title: Understanding and Strengthening EU Foreign and security Policy in a Complex and Contested World (JOINT)
projects.description:
JOINT is a project aimed at assessing challenges to a more joined-up foreign and security policy of the EU. These challenges have been mounting in recent years. Multipolar competition, fragmentation of regional politics, and fractious domestic debates directly affect the capacity of the EU and its member states to reconcile security priorities, allocate the resources to pursue these, and engage with external actors accordingly. 

JOINT, an interdisciplinary project involving 14 partners from 12 countries, investigates how to make EU foreign and security policy governance structures more joined-up and sustainable in a rapidly changing and contested international environment.

contributors.headline: Full Professor and Research Director at Maastricht University

projects.title: Who gets to live forever? Toward an Institutional Theory on the Decline and Death of International Organisations (NestIOr)
projects.description: This five-year project funded by the European Research Council (ERC) addresses the question why do international organisations (IOs) decline or die? Many IOs are currently under significant pressure resulting in the loss of competences, resources and even member states. The ultimate way for states to show their discontent is to disband IOs: no less than a third of the IOs, created between 1905 and 2005, has formally ceased to exist. While academics have analysed how IOs are designed and develop, we know virtually nothing about decline and death.

contributors.headline: Full Professor and Research Director at Maastricht University

projects.title: Preventing and Responding to Conflict: Developing EU Civilian Capabilities for a Sustainable Peace (EU-CIVCAP)
projects.description:
The European Union (EU) regularly sends policemen, rule of law experts, and monitors on civilian missions to other countries in order to prevent and respond to conflict. Among the 20+ civilian missions are recent deployments to Congo, Kosovo, Georgia and Ukraine. This research project analyses the capabilities which these policemen, rule of law experts and monitors need to properly carry out their functions. These capabilities range from armoured vehicles, to training and communcation systems. In addition to carrying out research, the project also has a strong dissemination component to help EU officials in improving civilian capabilities.

This large-scale project, funded under Horizon 2020 Secure Societies, is coordinated by the University of Bristol and contains ten universities, think tanks and EU agencies from across Europe. Researchers at Maastricht University focus on the EU civilian capabilities needed to respond to crises in comparison to other international organisations such as the UN and OSCE. They also analyse interactions between the EU, UN and OSCE in terms of civilian capabilities.

contributors.headline: Full Professor and Research Director at Maastricht University

projects.title: Beyond Sovereignty: Delegation and Agency in International Security
projects.description:
The United Nations (UN), North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and European Union (EU) currently have a record number of 250,000 troops deployed – up from 11,000 in 1989 and 90,000 in 2002. From Afghanistan to Congo, Haiti and Kosovo, these soldiers monitor inter-state agreements, provide stability and even fight insurgency. They oftentimes perform their duties in difficult environments. In their day-to-day operations, they are supported by a plethora of international secretariats in Brussels and New York employing thousands of civil servants. These secretariats play a vital role in the success or failure of military operations.

This project investigated why sovereign states delegate such important functions to international secretariats in international security. It also analysed under which conditions international secretariats exert influence in policy-making. The project was based at the University of Oxford and funded by the FP7 Marie Curie IEF Programme of the European Union.

authors.headline: Full Professor and Research Director at Maastricht University

profile_positions.description: The interdisciplinary research programme "Politics and Culture in Europe (PCE)" consists of 50 academic researchers from political science, history and philosophy and is the largest research programme at the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences. Responsibilities include setting intellectual priorities, research policy, recruitment and promotion, research colloquium, and research accreditation.
profile_positions.title: Director of Research Programme "Politics and Culture in Europe"

profile_positions.description:
I have carried out research on international organisations and European security in the context of five major EU-funded research project (ERC, H2020, Horizon Europe, Marie Curie). This has resulted in two monographs, a textbook, and various journal articles. I have also taught various courses on international relations, EU external relations and methods across the European Studies programmes (BA/MA/MSc). 

Research projects:
1) Project Coordinator, Horizon Europe-funded ENSURED project (2023-2026)
2) Work-Package Leader, Horizon 2020-funded JOINT project (2021-2024)
3) Principal Investigator, ERC Starting Grant (2019-2024)
4) Work-Package Leader, Horizon 2020-funded EU-CIVCAP project (2015-2018)
5) Main Researcher, EU Marie Curie Fellowship in Oxford (2012-2014)

Management roles:
1) Research Director, Research Programme "Politics and Culture in Europe" (2020-present)
2) Programme Director, MA European Studies (2018-2020)
3) Planning Team, New BA programme in Digital Society (2017-2019)

Board and advisory roles:
1) Member, Dutch Advisory Council on International Affairs (AIV) (2019-2027)
2) Member, Steering Committee of OSCE Network of Academic Institutions (2022-2023)
3) Board Member, Dutch Political Science Association (NKWP) (2019-2023)
4) Member, Advisory Council of Netherlands Institute of Governance (2021-2023)
5) Jury Member, H.A. Brasz Thesis Prize in Public Administration (2020-2021)
6) Board Member, Maastricht University Brussels Campus (2017-2021)

Editorial roles:
1) Editor-in-Chief, Contemporary Security Policy (2016-2023)
profile_positions.title: Full Professor of International Security and Cooperation

profile_positions.description: As Associate Professor I mostly worked on a large research project NestIOr funded by the European Research Council with a team of two postdocs and three PhD candidates. I concluded my term as Programme Director and the MA European Studies and started a new role as Director of the Research Programme "Politics and Culture in Europe".
profile_positions.title: Associate Professor

profile_positions.description: Tenured since January 2015. On leave from September 2012 to August 2014 as EU Marie Curie Fellow at the Department of Politics and International Relations at the University of Oxford.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: EU-funded project comparing the development and role of the UN Secretariat, NATO International Staff and European External Action Service in the area of military deployments.
profile_positions.title: Marie Curie Intra-European Fellow
